Award.AwardTitle: US-Japan Workshop on Future Directions for Earthquake Engineering Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract: US ? Japan Workshop on Future Directions for Earthquake Engineering Research
A US - Japan Workshop to explore future directions for earthquake engineering research is proposed for March 6-7, 2010 in Tokyo, Japan. Co-Chairs on the Japanese side are Professors Khoji Tokimatsu of the Tokyo Institute of Technology and Mitsumasa Midorikawa of the Hokkaido University. US co-Chairs are Professors James Wight of the University of Michigan and Mete Sozen of Purdue University. The primary purpose of the workshop will be to identify major challenges in earthquake engineering and to define research initiatives that will mitigate the social and financial impact of future earthquakes in the Asian-Pacific region. Workshop participants will be broadly based, and thus, will be intellectually free to define research thrust areas that have the highest potential to mitigate the earthquake threat without regard for where the research will be conducted and what agencies will finance the research. Workshop participants will be encouraged to pursue joint research projects that address major initiatives defined during the workshop and will facilitate a broader international exchange of students and young researchers between the US and Japan. The Workshop report will provide guidance for future research studies throughout the Asian-Pacific region, as well as for countries around the world facing an earthquake threat.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A US - Japan Workshop to explore future directions for earthquake engineering research was held March 6-7, 2010 in Tokyo, Japan. The Workshop was co-Chaired on the Japanese side by Professor Khoji Tokimatsu of the Tokyo Institute of Technology and Professor Mitsumasa Midorikawa of the Hokkaido University. The US co-Chairs were Professor James Wight of the University of Michigan and Professor Mete Sozen of Purdue University. Several earthquake engineering experts from the US and Japan were invited to participate in the workshop. The primary outcome from the workshop was a short list of critical research initiatives that have the potential to significantly decrease the earthquake risk to humans and critical infrastructure in the US, Japan and all of the earthquake-affected countries in the Asian-Pacific region.

The US and Japanese participants were requested to develop a list of research needs for initial presentations during the workshop. Each presentation was discussed and monitors were assigned to record the discussion and formulate topics for in-depth review during working group meetings. Four major topic areas were defined by this procedure for the working groups. Workshop participants were allowed to self-select the topic/working groups in which they prefer to participate.

The afternoon and early evening of the first day were devoted to working group discussions and the development of a report from each working group. The groups had one US and one Japanese leader, and at least one recorder. Those people were charged with developing a presentation from their working group for the morning of the second day. At the mid-afternoon break, participants were permitted to switch working groups so they could give input to an additional working group that was covering a topic of interest to them.

The second day started with presentations from each of the working groups. Presentation times were limited to allow ample opportunity for full-group discussions. One purpose of the discussions were to define how to implement the conclusions and recommendations from each group. Monitors were assigned to record the major conclusions and recommendations. After breaking for lunch and dismissing most of the workshop participants, the Workshop Co-Chairs and monitors spent the afternoon refining and editing the major conclusions and recommend-dations from the workshop. They also agreed on how this information was to be shared with the earthquake engineering research communities in both the US and Japan. The primary research thrusts defined during the workshop are:

Develop Sustainable, Predictable Materials and Systems for Structural and Geotechnical Applications

What – Sustainable, Predictable Earthquake-Resistant Structural and Geotechnical Systems

Why – Optimize use of resources and protect the environment.

How – Experimental development of materials and systems; Develop light, energy-efficient, renewable, repairable, self-adjusting materials; Develop resilient, reconfigurable, easy to assemble systems.

Expected Results – Reduction in loss of life; Reduced cost of construction and maintenance; Reduced cost of post-EQ damage; Resilient geotechnical, structural, and lifeline systems.
